attributes.definition: Attributes that have no inherent order.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Nominal data are categories without any ranking, like colors or types of fruit.

extractions.extraction_text: Ordinal attributes have an order but not equal spacing.

attributes.definition: Attributes that have a meaningful order but the spacing between values is not uniform or quantifiable.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Ordinal data have a rank order, but the difference between ranks isn't consistent, like 'small', 'medium', 'large'.

extractions.extraction_text: Interval attributes have equal spacing but no true zero.

attributes.definition: Attributes with equal spacing between values, but lacking a true zero point (where zero means the absence of the quantity).
attributes.simplified_explanation: Interval data have consistent intervals, but zero doesn't mean 'nothing', like temperature (0Â°C is not the absence of heat).

extractions.extraction_text: Ratio data you can do equal and then you can also do proportional. So that is. You can see there's a very tiny word called true zero ratio data. You do have something called zero. The zero means zero, nothing.

attributes.definition: Attributes with equal spacing and a true zero point, allowing for proportional comparisons.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Ratio data have consistent intervals and a true zero, meaning zero represents the complete absence of the quantity, like height or weight.

extractions.extraction_text: Nominal values can only distinguish one object from another.

attributes.definition: Values that can only be used to distinguish one object from another.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Nominal values are labels used for identification, not for ordering or measurement.

extractions.extraction_text: The zero means zero, nothing. You need to know true zero means not just because they have a value called zero. That zero also means if zero does not mean nothing. Then it is not true zero.

attributes.summary_of_insight: A 'true zero' in ratio data signifies the complete absence of the measured quantity.

extractions.extraction_text: The slide is titled "Types of Attributes". It presents a table categorizing different types of attributes: Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio. Each category has a checkmark indicating its properties. Nominal attributes have no order. Ordinal attributes have an order but not equal spacing. Interval attributes have equal spacing but no true zero. Ratio attributes have equal spacing and a true zero. The slide also shows a visual representation of these types on a number line, indicating increasing order and spacing from left to right.

attributes.description: The slide is titled "Types of Attributes". It presents a table categorizing different types of attributes: Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio. Each category has a checkmark indicating its properties. Nominal attributes have no order. Ordinal attributes have an order but not equal spacing. Interval attributes have equal spacing but no true zero. Ratio attributes have equal spacing and a true zero. The slide also shows a visual representation of these types on a number line, indicating increasing order and spacing from left to right.
attributes.pedagogical_purpose: To introduce and define the four main types of data attributes and their characteristics.

extractions.extraction_text: Nominal data, again, if you try to do data mining process, the nominal data you need to set it as categorical data.

attributes.definition: Data that can only be categorized, not measured or ordered. It needs to be treated as categorical data in data mining.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Nominal data is for categories without any order, like colors or types of fruit. It should be treated as categories in analysis.

extractions.extraction_text: So right now, the zip code is look like number. It's like 0013. It looks like number. But you shouldn't set it as number. You shouldn't set it as numerical data. You need to set it as string or you set it as nominal data or categorical data.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Treat zip codes as nominal/categorical data (strings), not numerical data, even though they look like numbers.

extractions.extraction_text: Because string can also only do equal and not equal.

attributes.summary_of_insight: When data is treated as a string or nominal, the only operations possible are equality checks (equal/not equal).

extractions.extraction_text: But from a population, if you want to say, oh, I have so many zip code data. What can I do? You can have some distribution. How many people are in this zip code? So you can find a distribution. Or you can find who are the county have the majority of the people. Something like that.

attributes.summary_of_insight: To analyze nominal data like zip codes, you can look at distributions (e.g., count of people per zip code) or identify dominant categories (e.g., county with most people).

text:
# LECTURE ANALYSIS: Types of Attributes
## Video Segment: 83:20

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Types of Attributes". It presents a table categorizing different types of attributes: Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio. Each category has a checkmark indicating its properties. Nominal attributes have no order. Ordinal attributes have an order but not equal spacing. Interval attributes have equal spacing but no true zero. Ratio attributes have equal spacing and a true zero. The slide also shows a visual representation of these types on a number line, indicating increasing order and spacing from left to right.

[TRANSCRIPT - 83:20]

And usually they will only give you two choice. One is called categorical data. One is another is called number. So right now, the zip code is look like number. It's like 0013. It looks like number. But you shouldn't set it as number. You shouldn't set it as numerical data. You need to set it as string or you set it as nominal data or categorical data. Depends on what kind of thing.
